comment.author: 35607158@N06
comment._content: Just out of curiosity what is the FOIPOP on this? Was it deemed to be a public document in the first place, or does some 30/50/75 year rule apply or did you have to get it cleared?

comment.author: 23121382@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/jamica1] Borrowing records are covered by the Municpal Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Act (www.e-laws.gov.on.ca/html/statutes/english/elaws_statutes...). Advice today to libraries is to dispose of borrowing records after one year. After a lapse of 92 years the personal information in these pages is much less sensitive (particularly compared to the information released in the 1921 census, for example).

comment.author: 35607158@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/deserontoarchives] Interesting, I was just wondering on a couple of counts. At my university for instance a librarian could not tell me if my student X borrowed book Y as that would violate their privacy. And I recall at the City of Toronto archives years ago having to file (and pay the fee) for a FOI review of a file before I could look at it -- the file was technical specifications for street paving c. 1934.
